Nebraska Agricultural Statistics 1925 ISSUED COOPERATIVELY BY United States Department of Agriculture / Division of Crop and Livestock Estimates AND Nebraska State Department of Agriculture Division of Agricultural Statistics h. j. Mclaughlin .Secretary of Agriculture Compiled by A. E. ANDERSON State and Federal Statistician LINCOLN, NEBRASKA
CLAFLIN PRINTING CO.. UNIVERSITY PLACE, NEBR.
\ H. J. Mclaughlin Secretary of Agriculture

5 To His Excellency: HON. ADAM McMULLEN, Governor of Nebraska. Sir: Special endeavor has been made in this report to publish historical as well as the present records of agriculture so they will not only be preserved but also be made available to meet present increasing demand, as the annual reports for years previous to 1923 are exhausted. This report is by far the most detailed and complete issued to date and covers the entire field of crops, livestock, and practically all other agricultural commodities pro - duced in the state. A glance at the index will reveal the vast quantity of agricultural records contained. The 1925 crops may be classed as fair. Winter wheat produced 60% of the usual crop due to a 2 1 % abandonment and poor yields. This led to a heavy increase in acreage of oats and corn. Hay crops were below usual. There was a heavy reduction in hogs, and less livestock was fed. However, the state arose from sixth in value of all crops to fifth place in 1925. The rank in value of livestock dropped from fourth to fifth in 1925. Considering both crops and livestock, the state's previous high rank has been maintained. The value of crops at December prices was $309,954,000 as compared to $361,842,000 in 1924. If we add to this the increase in value brought by corn fed to livestock, the 1925 value of crops will approximate the 1924 values. The value of livestock January 1, 1926 was $256,000,000 as compared to $240,000,000 the previous year even though numbers were reduced. A total of 5356,000 hogs were marketed in 1925 which brought $133,925,000. Cattle marketings reached 1,623,000 head, and a most conservative estimate of value is at least $100,000,000. The state marketed 1,116,000 sheep that brought $11,000,000. The recent rapid development of the dairy and poultry industries is out-standing. The value of milk at farm prices advanced from $29,232,000 in 1921 to $46,421,000 in 1925. The calf crop from milk cows at the close of the year was worth $10,000,000 at farm prices. Poultry and eggs produced in 1925 were worth $30,946,000 at farm prices. In view of the foregoing facts, it will be seen that Nebraska agriculture is bringing large returns in comparison with the past decade or two. However, the returns are not on a par with the rise in land values, or the prices that farmers have to pay for manu - factured articles. On June 1, 1925, the Nebraska Department of Agriculture revised its co-operative agreement with the federal Division of Crop and Livestock Estimates to publish crop reports. The two offices were combined and the federal office was moved to the State House, and the work placed in charge of the federal statistician. So far, this arrangement has been satisfactory. It has eliminated duplication of effort and assured greater uniformity in the preparation of reports from year to year, a point most essential because their value lies in the comparison from year to year. Changes in the method of preparation destroys the comparability. It is difficult to maintain comparability when the head of the office is changed every two or four years. The value of agricultural statistics is becoming more appreciated. The standing and progress of agriculture, like other industries, cannot be determined and its problems met without adequate statistics. The old idea that agricultural statistics benefits the speculator and injures the farmer is rapidly being reversed. All are beginning to realize that the maximum farm prices cannot be obtained until the facts on production and demand are first determined. Injurious speculation cannot exist when the facts are known. Market dealers will not pay as high prices for products when uncertainty of production exists be - cause of the large handling risk involved. H. J. McLaughlin. Secretary of Agriculture.

31 WHEAT FARM OPERATIONS Plowing for Wheat, Saline County Nearly 14,000 gas tractors and 740,000 work horses and mules used in oper - ating 20.000,000 acres harvested on 127,000 farms and ranches. Nearly 10.000 threshers used to thresh and separate 128,000,000 bushels of small grain. Very little straw is baled, most of it is burned. Threshing Wheat, Phelps County Baling Wheat Straw, Harlan County

33 CORN, WHEAT AND OATS Nebraska is third in corn and third in winter wheat. Over 14,088,000 acres devoted to corn, wheat and oats with an average production of 336,846,000 bushels. The acreage of these three crops exceeds the acreage of all crops in 15 states. Corn, Wayne County Wheat, Kearney County Oats, Burt County

63 FORAGE CROPS Over a quarter million acres of millet, sudan and sweet sor - ghum producing over two-thirds of a million tons annually. Su - dan nearly trebled in past six years. Sweet Sorghum, Adams County Sudan, Fillmore County Nebraska ranked first in hay and forage production with 7,864,000 tons in 1924. StaU ranked second in acreage in 1925. Millet, Furnas County

65 CABBAGE AND CANTALOUPES Cabbages, Adams County Over 127,000 farm gardens supply home needs of vegetables. An enormous surplus could be produced on Nebraska's fertile fields, but the Cornhusker farmer has little time for small truck on his aver - age farm of 376 acres. Cantaloupes, Seward County

149 HISTORY OF CROP REPORTING IN NEBRASKA "The United Stales Department of Agriculture was organized in the year 1862 and the head of the department was entitled "Commissioner of Agriculture". The year book of the department for the year 1885 page 14, discloses that crop reporting originated with the department in the year 1865, reports being received from crop reporters in 1,800 counties. Hon. William G. LeDuc was commissioner of agriculture in the period 1876-1880 and in his report as commissioner published in the 1880 year book page 13, advises that the de - partment had 4,000 crop reporters. Commissioner Hon. George B. Loring in the 1884 year book, page 9, reported 10,000 correspondents who served the department as crop reporters. Commissioner Hon. Norman J. Colman in the 1886 year book, page 22 reports 2,300 counties having an average of four crop reporters to a county, a total of nearly 10,000 reporters. In the year 1889 the office of Secretary of Agriculture was created by act of Congress. The secretary being a member of the cabinet of the president. Hon. J. M. Rusk of Wis - consin was the first Secretary of Agriculture and in his first report as secretary (see 1889 year book, page 33) says, that the department has 1 1 ,000 correspondents serving as crop reporters. Hon. J. Sterling Morton became Secretary of Agriculture in 1893 and in his report as secretary (see 1895 year book, page 33) says, "10,000 crop reporters in 2,500 counties throughout several states and territories of the American Union perform their duties without any pecuniary remuneration whatever. Added to the foregoing unremunerated force there are 15,000 millers and elevator men who send in figures and data from month to month relative to cereal and other crops, and also 15,000 township correspondents who do the same thing and 6,000 agents (crop reporters) who report to the several state statistical agents". And in conclusion Mr. Morton sums up by saying, "and supplementing all the foregoing there are 125,000 American farmers who also assist in furnishing like information. " In the 1897 year book, page 56, Hon. James Wilson, Secretary of Agriculture, reports 56,700 regular crop reporters and 149,500 special correspondents reporting at special sea - sons of the year. In 1905 year book, page 96, Secretary Wilson slates that there are ap - proximately 2,700 counties of agricultural importance. The statistical agents are paid agents located in 43 states. The statistical agent reports for his state and maintains a corp of correspondents entirely independent of those reporting directly to the department at Washington. In the 1917 year book, page 94, Secretary David F. Houston reports ap - proximately 175,000 voluntary crop reporters mostly fanners, one in each agricultural township, one or more in each county, and a large number who report on special crops or classes of livestock. Crop Reporting in Nebraska There are no records available to disclose who first served as statistical agent for Nebraska. Daniel H. Wheeler of Plattsmouth, served as secretary of the State Board of Agriculture in the periods 1870-1880 and also 1882-1883, and the records seem to dis - close that Mr. Wheeler was Nebraska's first statistical agent duly appointed by the United States Department of Agriculture, the date of his appointment unknown. The writer first began service as a crop reporter in 1876 under state statistical agent, D. H. Wheeler who was also serving as secretary of the State Board of Agriculture. The writer attended his first Nebraska State Fair, at Lincoln, in September 1876 (and did not miss in attendance at a State Fair for thirty years) and there first met Major Wheeler, and it is believed the writer's services as crcp reporter dates from that time for the reason, that not only were all members of the State Board of Agriculture volunteer crop reporters but practically all persons interested in the work of the State Board and of the State Fair. The year books of the Nebraska State Board of Agriculture discloses that at an annual meeting the State Board appropriated $100.00 to enable Secretary Wheeler, statistical agent for Nebraska, to furnish for publication in the press of the state, and in the year book of the State Board a summary of his crop report, and in the 1884 year book, page 107, may be found such a report signed "D. H. Wheeler, Statistical Agent", in which Mr. Wheeler states that he has received crop reports from 68 counties; that he had 120 crop reporters and had received reports from 95 of them. In the September 1, 1871 issue of a local newspaper, The Nebraska Atlas, mention is made of the appointment of W. W. Cox of Seward County as Statistical correspondent of the Department of Agriculture. History of Seward County by W. W. Cox, page 73. So far as can be learned this is the first published mention in which is given the name of a crop reporter in Nebraska.

150 It it doubtless the case that Eli A. Barnes, of Grand Island is in length of service, the oldest crop reporter for Nebraska living in 1920. Mr. Barnes' services as a crop reporter began at an early date, about 1870, and have continued to date. Under date, Grand Island, Nebraska, January 10, 1920 Mr. Barnes writes, "I cannot fix the date I commenced crop reporting in Nebraska, I know I reported to D. H. Wheeler and have continued reporting ever since." Mr. Barnes, a soldier of the Civil War, was a homestead settler in Hall County at an early date and was officially connected with the Nebraska State Board of Agriculture as early as 1870. In the year 1881, at a State Fair held in Omaha, there was held on the State Fair grounds a meeting of the crop reporters of the state, the call for the meeting being issued by state statistical agent D. H. Wheeler. At this meeting there was organized a state crop reporting association with Major Wheeler as president, and the writer, secretary. As re - called there were some 15 or 20 crop reporters in attendance but it cannot be recalled that another inch meeting was held. In the year 1884, R. W. Furnas was elected secretary of the State Board of Agricul - ture and the records seem to disclose that in the year 1887 R. W. Furnas succeeded D. H. Wheeler as Statistical Agent for Nebraska. At the annual meeting of the Board of Agriculture, January 19, 1887 Mr. Furnas offered the following resolution which was unanimously adopted: "Resolved, That this board cheerfully and without hesitation, recommend that United States. Commissioner of Agriculture, Colman, appoint as State Statistician for Nebraska, Eli A. Barnes. Believing such appointment would result greatly to the advantage of agriculture in the new west." (Year book, State Board of Agriculture, 1886, page 52.) In the year book of the Board of Agriculture, page 6, Secretary Furnas says, "I have in Nebraska 1,500 individuals who render aid in making up crop reports," and in 1889 year book, page 69, he states that he had from 10 to 20 correspondents in each county. In the earlier history of the state the naming of a state statistical agent was considered a political plum at the disposal of the political party in power, and it appears, (largely from memory) that about the year 18%- 1897, Mr. Furnas, learning that the "Political Powers that be" desired to name another statistical agent, had in mind to tender his resignation, and Eli A. Barnes of Grand Island, a member of the State Board of Agriculture, and also a crop reporter, conferred with Mr. Furnas in the matter of his resignation. At that date, 1896-1897, the writer was a member of the Board of Agriculture, and was informed by Mr. Barnes that he was an applicant for the position of state statistical agent for Nebraska. It is the judgment of the writer that Mr. Furnas did not voluntarily resign as statistical agent, for the reason that the work of statistical agent was congenial to Mr. Furnas, whose life was largely devoted to the development of agriculture in Nebraska, and further, that the work of statistical agent was directly in line with much of the work of the State Board of Agriculture. W. G. Whitmore, who succeeded Mr. Furnas as statistical agent for Nebraska about the year 1897, under date of December 30, 1919, writes as follows: "The first I ever heard of the resignation of Governor Furnas was a telegram from Dave Mercer, then a member of Congress saying there was a vacancy and that (Edward) Rosewater was hustl - ing to have the naming of Furnas' successor, I do not remember who it was. Mr. Mercer informed me there had been a consultation among the Nebraska members in both house and Congress, and without my knowledge or consent they had agreed to offer the appointment to me, and that all I had to do was to accept, which I did." Mr. Whitmore adds, "There was, as I remember, not a line of any sort among the things received from my predecessor, to indicate that there had been a statistical agent before him. No list of correspondents serving under either Mr. Wheeler or Mr. Furnas had been preserved." Mr. Whitmore states, "the salary of the statistical agent was $800.00 per year paid by the government, being less than was paid a competent clerk to assist in the actual work of compiling and getting out the reports." Mr. Whitmore was an exceedingly busy man in those days, having large and varied financial interests and the records seem to disclose that in the year 1913, at his suggestion the statistical agency was turned over to the state experiment station and placed in charge of C. W. Pugsley, director of the station. Under date of January 27, 1920, Mr. Pugsley writes, "I received $800.00 a year from the general government. This amount was deducted from my University salary, but I was permitted to hire a clerk to assist in tabulation of reports. I handled the work as an individual, not as a university employee. I had about 250 crop correspondents. At the close of my services Mr. Anderson went on as full time man."

151 Under dale of May 18. 1920, A. E. Anderson writes, "C. W. Pugsley terminated his services as stale statistical agent June 30, 1914. Upon that date the office of state statis - tical agent was abolished in all states. In place of this the number of field agents was increased until there was one for every state or group of small states. Heretofore, a field agent had several states, ranging from two to four or five. "State statistical agents devoted only a part of their time to the work. The field agent devotes all of his time to the work. For the territory of which the state of Neb - raska is a part the first special field agent was Thomas B. Baldwin, who was appointed about July I, 1897 and who was succeeded by Frank S. Pinney, who was appointed July 6, 1905, and served until June 30, 1914. "A. E. Anderson was appointed field agent for Nebraska July 6, 1914, and is still (1920) serving in that capacity. His office is located in rooms 213-214 of the post office building, Lincoln. Miss Lottie E. Emerson was appointed clerk in the office November I, 1917." "On May 18, 1918. E> R. Danielson, Secretary of the Nebraska State Board of Agriculture, signed an agreement with the Bureau of Crop Statistics, U. S. Department of Agriculture, to publish cooperative crop reports. The purpose of this cooperation was to prevent duplication and to develop the work further. The first cooperative crop report was issued July 1, 1918." "At the time A. E. Anderson took charge of the office July 6, 1914, Field Agent Pinney turned over a list of 151 crop correspondents and state statistical agent C. W. Pugsley a list of 283 crop correspondents, making a total of 436 crop correspondents. These com - prise the regular lists of correspondents who report monthly and oftener if called upon. Neither had any special lists at that time." "The present (1920) lists of crop reporters who send their reports to this office at Lincoln are as follows: Field aids 931, these are the regular correspondents who report monthly and at other times when called upon ; special grain aids 304, these report upon gram crops ; special live stock aids 201 , these report upon livestock ; special commercial potato aids 82, these report upon the_ commercial potato crop only ; special seed aids 75, these report on seed crops ; special bean aids 55, these report on beans only. The bean aid list was used during the war only and there will probably be no further use for it as the bean industry in Nebraska is not important now ; special bee aids 225, these report on bees and honey. This list was handled at the Washington office two years ago and the reports have been sent direct to the Washington office; special field aids 4,021, these report once a year for the final county estimates. "In addition to the above the following number of crop reporters for Nebraska send their reports direct to the Washington office: Township reporters 1,074; county reporters 87: mill and elevator reporters 1 ,005 ; individual farm reporters 1 ,003 ; livestock reporters 513; special sheep reporters 92 ; potato reporters 1 87 ; honey bee reporters 54 ; apple reporters 176; special price reporters 200." "The total of all correspondents for Nebraska reporting to this office (Lincoln) and direct to the Washington office is 10385." For additional information relating to crop reporting in Nebraska and statistics of crop production, attention is invited to a most comprehensive and valuable summary in the 1915 Nebraska blue book, pages 760-777 edited by Director A. E. Sheldon and published by the legislative reference bureau. In the year books of the United States Department of Agriculture from the year 1880 to date, may be found much information relating to crop production in the United States as a whole and to Nebraska as a state, the same being in a brief official summary form, the work of the crop reporting service of the department. Also in the year books of the Nebraska State Board of Agriculture may be found, in statistical form, records of crop production in the state from the year 1880 to 1919. Under the provision of the code bill, enacted into a statute at the 1919 session of the state legislature, the Department of Agriculture has taken up the cooperative crop reporting work with the U. S. Department of Agriculture, which was initiated by the State Board of Agriculture on May 18, 1918." S. C. BASSETT. Dated March 6, 1921. Editor's Note. Mr. S. C. Bassett has the record of longest service as a crop reporter in Nebraska. For fifty long years, 1876 to the time of his death in 1926, he generously

152 volunteered his valued services for the public interest without remuneration. For this reason, at well at the fact that records of the early history of the crop reporting service are lacking, it is both fitting and fortunate that he added to his many contributions to Nebraska Agri - culture, his history of the crop reporting service. Much credit is due Mr. Bassett for this and his long list of achievements to the cause of agriculture in Nebraska. History of Crop Report»t in Nebraska, 1921 to 1926 In order to extend the history of Nebraska Crop Reporting to the present date, 1926. the following chapter has been prepared by A. EL Anderson who still has charge of the work. The most important event in the earlier history of Nebraska crop reporting was the law that required the collection of crop statistics through the assessors. Perhaps second in importance to this was the consolidation of the state and federal crop statistical agencies in 1918. This prevented duplication, enabled the combined agency to prepare more com - plete reports, and permitted greater opportunity for development. Since a uniform method was inaugurated and maintained from year to year after the consolidation, the annual esti - mates became comparable, and herein lies the value of the work. Nebraska was among the first states to cooperate with the federal government in this work. At present, nearly all of the leading agricultural states are doing likewise. This has led to a more uniform system throughout the nation, and world recognition of the fact that the United States excels in crop reporting work has led to the appointment of a former chief of the Federal Division of Crop and Livestock Estimates, Mr. Leon M. Estabrook, to take charge of the world census of agriculture in 1930. Due to the inactivity of the Nebraska Department of Agriculture in crop reporting work in 1923 and 1924 which resulted in a greatly increased quantity of work for the federal department. Miss Edith Heed was appointed as a second federal clerk September 1, 1923 after having served for some time under a temporary appointment. While the aband - onment of the state statistical work was said to be taken to economize, the facts are that the cost of the service to the state has never exceeded two and a half cents per tax payer. Many private concerns spend several times the amount spent by the state in an endeavor to profit by the advance crop information similar to which the state is furnishing the farmer so he may have the same advantage without being misled by private reports issued for personal gain. It was only through exceptionally hard work that the records for 1923 and 1924 were finally compiled and preserved to maintain an unbroken record of Nebraska agriculture. In June, 1925, the cooperative crop reporting work was greatly improved through a revised contract with the federal government. The federal department moved its offices to the State House and the consolidated office was placed under direct charge of A. E. Ander - son, and was called the State and Federal Divison of Agricultural Statistics. Mr. F. K. Reed was appointed as assistant state and federal statistician, September 25, 1925. Two clerks of the State Department of Agriculture, Mrs. L. G. Strombeck and Miss Bonnie J. Copenhaver, were designated to assist in the crop reporting work when needed. Mrs. Lottie E. Kelly who has served as Chief Clerk for the federal office since Nov. 1. 1917 is still serving in that capacity. Since the renewed cooperation with the Federal Department in 1925, all of the state's agricultural records have been assembled and printed so that nearly all available informa - tion on Nebraska Agriculture will be found either in the 1923-24 report, or the 1925 report. Statistical reports for the previous years are not available, so it was deemed advisable to assemble the past records in order to preserve and make them available. Records of Nebraska's greatest industry are increasing in interest and value as time moves on. Much credit is due Mr. H. J. McLaughlm, present Secretary of Agriculture for his nterest and action in developing the crop reporting service toward its highest state of fEciency without increasing the cost to the state. Much credit is also due the 5,000 field rop reporters who are volunteering their services without pay to make this work possible. sst, but not least, the deputy assessors through the annual collection of acreage data are >erform<ng a very essential work in- making the service a success. Nothing less than con - inuoet publication of authentic crop reports will enable price to respond to demand. In - uffici'nt reports will invariably work against the interests of farmers due to the additional risk of purchase and ownership by dealers which prompts them to offer less in order to reduce their risk when uncertainty prevails. Dated March 12, 1926. A. E. ANDERSON.

153 SCENIC NEBRASKA The spreading fertile plains, wide river valleys, magnificent fields of corn, wheat, oats and alfalfa, splendid farm homes and fine live - stock greet all with unsurpassed scenes and views, in Nebraska where agriculture reigns supreme. Nature's scenery, even that of the beauti - ful Yosemite valley offers no better view than Nebraska's waving fields of golden grain and hay. No state depends so much on agriculture for its prosperity as Nebraska ; the land of greatest surplus food production. Canyons, Gosper County Nature's Work, Knox County
